text: We rarely scale a project, a product we've launched, until we know the Sean Ellis score and we know that it's hit a threshold that we find really compelling. The Sean Ellis score is a really simple methodology used by lots and lots of companies that a gentleman named Sean Ellis popularized well over a decade ago.
speaker: Jag Duggal
context: Lenny asks about how Nubank measures whether customers truly love their products before scaling them. Jag explains that they use the Sean Ellis score methodology, which asks customers how disappointed they would be if the product went away. At Nubank, they require at least 50% of customers to say they would be 'very disappointed' before scaling a product, which is higher than the typical 40% threshold due to Brazilian customers being more polite and optimistic.
vocabulary_highlights: popularized well over a decade ago
text_ko: 저희는 보통 프로젝트나 출시된 제품을 바로 확장(scale)하지 않아요. 먼저 션 엘리스 스코어(Sean Ellis score)를 확인해서 그 점수가 저희가 정말 매력적이라고 느끼는 기준(threshold)을 넘을 때까지 기다려요. 션 엘리스 스코어는 션 엘리스(Sean Ellis)라는 분이 10년이 훨씬 넘게 전에 널리 알린, 많은 회사들이 쓰는 아주 단순한 방법론이에요.
text_zh: 我们很少会去扩大一个项目或者已经上线的产品规模，除非我们知道肖恩·埃利斯得分(Sean Ellis score)，而且确认它达到了我们认为很有说服力的那个门槛。肖恩·埃利斯得分(Sean Ellis score)其实是个很简单的方法论，现在很多很多公司都在用，是一个叫肖恩·埃利斯的人在十多年前推广开的。
text_es: Casi nunca escalamos un proyecto o un producto que hemos lanzado hasta que conocemos el puntaje de Sean Ellis y sabemos que ha alcanzado un umbral que nos parece realmente atractivo. El puntaje de Sean Ellis (Sean Ellis score) es una metodología súper sencilla que usan muchísimas empresas y que un señor llamado Sean Ellis popularizó hace más de una década.
key_sentence: We know the Sean Ellis score has hit a threshold we find really compelling.

text: Good enough, isn't good enough. Is it great enough? Because that's the bar, particularly for some of our ten-pole products, but we try to apply it largely across the board. A lot of companies spend a ton of money on marketing. Their VC budgets, VC funding basically goes to Google and Facebook.
speaker: Jag Duggal
context: Lenny is asking about Nubank's approach to building products people love fanatically. Jag shares a phrase from their lead designer about raising the bar beyond just 'good enough' to 'great enough.' He explains this philosophy helps them avoid spending heavily on marketing since truly great products generate word-of-mouth growth instead of requiring massive advertising budgets.
text_ko: '그냥 괜찮다' 수준으론 안 돼요. 충분히 훌륭한가요? 그게 기준이에요. 특히 몇몇 주력 제품에는 더 그렇고, 가능한 한 전반에 걸쳐 적용하려고 해요. 많은 회사가 마케팅에 엄청난 돈을 써요. 그들의 벤처캐피털(VC) 자금은 사실상 구글과 페이스북으로 가요.
text_zh: 差不多好，那可不够。得问问是不是真的够棒？这就是我们的标准，特别是对那些十柱产品(ten-pole products)，但我们基本上全线都这么要求。很多公司在营销上砸大钱，风投资金(VC funding)基本上都流到谷歌和脸书那儿去了。
text_es: "Suficientemente bueno" no es suficiente. ¿Es lo suficientemente genial? Porque ese es el estándar, especialmente para algunos de nuestros productos estrella (ten-pole products), pero tratamos de aplicarlo en general a todo. Muchas empresas se gastan una fortuna en marketing. Sus presupuestos de capital de riesgo, básicamente la financiación de VC se va directo a Google y Facebook.
key_sentence: Good enough isn't good enough; we aim for great enough across the board.

text: Don't ask a researcher to come up with a plan to go do the research to then summarize it, to then bring it to you, which has so many degrees of distance built in. You pick up the phone, call 10 of them and nine times out of 10, by the time you've made your fifth call, you could predict what's customer six, seven, eight, nine and 10 are going to tell you.
speaker: Jag Duggal
context: Lenny asks about how product managers can get closer to customer feedback. Jag explains Nubank's approach of having product managers directly call customers rather than going through multiple layers of research intermediaries. He advocates for this direct approach because it eliminates the distance between the product builder and customer voice, and patterns emerge quickly after just a few conversations.
text_ko: 연구자한테 '조사 계획 짜고, 연구해서 요약해 가져와라'고 시키지 마세요. 그건 중간 단계가 너무 많아서 거리감이 생겨요. 그냥 전화를 들어 열 명 정도에게 직접 물어보세요. 열 번 중 아홉 번은 다섯 번째 통화까지 해보면 나머지 사람들이 뭐라고 할지 다 예측할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 别让研究员先做个研究计划，然后去调研，再总结汇报给你，这中间隔了好几层。你直接拿起电话打给10个客户，十有八九，打到第五个的时候，你就能猜到后面几个客户会跟你说什么了。
text_es: No le pidas a un investigador que te arme un plan para hacer la investigación, después resumirla y luego traértela—eso tiene demasiados filtros de por medio. Mejor agarra el teléfono, llama directamente a 10 clientes, y te aseguro que en 9 de cada 10 casos, para cuando hagas la quinta llamada, ya vas a poder predecir exactamente qué te van a decir los clientes seis, siete, ocho, nueve y diez.
key_sentence: You could predict customer responses nine times out of 10 with direct calls.

text: We are not going to take a small problem and scale it because if we do that, we end up with a big mess. Something isn't working at small scale, no problem, especially if we have a strong hypothesis and a lot of ways of getting good customer feedback. We iterate, we iterate, we get it right and then once we get it right, scaling if you do it right in many cases takes care of itself.
speaker: Jag Duggal
context: Lenny is discussing the pressures product managers face to scale products quickly. Jag explains Nubank's disciplined approach of not scaling products until they have achieved product-market fit at a small scale. He emphasizes that it's better to solve problems when they're small rather than create bigger messes by scaling prematurely, and that proper scaling often happens naturally once the product is truly working.
vocabulary_highlights: end up with a big mess
text_ko: 작은 문제를 그대로 확장(scale)하진 않을 거예요. 그렇게 하면 결국 큰 난장판이 되거든요. 작은 규모에서 잘 안 되면 괜찮아요. 특히 명확한 가설(hypothesis)이 있고 고객 피드백(customer feedback)을 받을 방법이 많다면요. 계속 반복(iterate)해서 개선해요. 제대로 맞출 때까지요. 그리고 일단 제대로 맞추면, 확장(scale)은 많은 경우 저절로 해결돼요.
text_zh: 我们不会拿一个小问题直接放大，因为那样做最后就是一团糟。如果在小规模时就有问题，其实没关系，特别是当我们有很强的假设和很多渠道能拿到好的客户反馈。我们就不断迭代(iterate)，不断迭代，直到做对为止。一旦做对了，扩张这件事如果方法得当，很多时候就是水到渠成的事。
text_es: No vamos a agarrar un problema chiquito y escalarlo porque si hacemos eso, terminamos con un desastre enorme. Si algo no está funcionando a pequeña escala, no hay bronca, sobre todo si tenemos una hipótesis sólida y muchas formas de conseguir buen feedback de los clientes. Iteramos, iteramos, lo hacemos bien y después, una vez que lo tenemos bien, el escalamiento, si lo haces correctamente, en muchos casos se cuida solo.
key_sentence: We won't scale a small problem; it could end up with a big mess.

text: We may not be right, but at least we are clear. Even if your strategy isn't right, and it will never be exactly right because no plan ever is, you will have a clearer read on if you are going off course because you have a very clear idea of what was supposed to be happening.
speaker: Jag Duggal
context: Lenny asks Jag about his approach to strategy development. Jag quotes Kevin Systrom from Instagram's early days to illustrate the importance of strategic clarity. He argues that having a clear strategy, even if imperfect, allows teams to quickly identify when they're going off course because they have concrete expectations about what should be happening.
text_ko: 우리가 꼭 옳지 않을 수도 있지만, 적어도 상황은 분명해요. 전략이 완전히 맞을 수는 없어요—어떤 계획도 완벽하진 않으니까요. 하지만 무엇이 일어나야 하는지 분명히 알고 있으면, 우리가 방향을 벗어나고 있는지 훨씬 더 빨리, 더 정확하게 파악할 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们可能不一定对，但至少我们心里有数。就算你的策略不完全正确——其实也不可能完全正确，因为没有哪个计划是完美的——但你至少能清楚地知道自己是不是走偏了，因为你对原本应该怎么走心里很清楚。
text_es: Puede que no tengamos la razón, pero al menos tenemos las cosas claras. Aunque tu estrategia no sea la correcta, y nunca va a ser perfecta porque ningún plan lo es, vas a poder darte cuenta mucho mejor si te estás desviando del camino porque tienes muy claro qué se suponía que tenía que pasar.
key_sentence: A clearer read on strategy helps identify if you're going off course.

text: We're not trying to be incrementally better. We are trying to be fundamentally different. We're in the business of being fundamentally different, not incrementally better. Only fundamentally different, gets customers to tell their friends. Incrementally better and there are certain features where you're in the incrementally better business, but we're searching for those anchors that are going to be fundamentally different all the time.
speaker: Jag Duggal
context: Lenny is asking about Nubank's philosophy and approach to product development. Jag explains their core principle that appears on company mugs - they focus on being fundamentally different rather than incrementally better. He clarifies that while some features may be incremental improvements, they constantly search for anchor products and experiences that are fundamentally different because only those drive word-of-mouth growth.
text_ko: 우리는 단지 점진적 개선(incrementally better)을 하려는 게 아니에요. 우리는 근본적 차이(fundamentally different)를 만들려고 해요. 우리의 사업은 점진적 개선이 아니라 근본적 차이를 만드는 일이에요. 고객이 친구에게 소개하게 만드는 건 오직 근본적으로 다른 것뿐이에요. 물론 어떤 기능들은 점진적 개선의 영역에 있어서 그걸 하는 경우도 있지만, 우리는 항상 근본적으로 다를 핵심 요소(anchors)를 찾고 있어요.
text_zh: 我们不是想做得稍微好一点点，我们是要做得完全不一样。我们要做的就是根本性的差异化，而不是小修小补的改进。只有做到根本性的不同，客户才会主动给朋友推荐。如果只是稍微改进一下，当然某些功能确实需要渐进式优化，但我们一直在寻找那些能让我们彻底与众不同的核心支撑点。
text_es: No estamos buscando ser un poquito mejores que la competencia. Estamos tratando de ser radicalmente diferentes. Nuestro negocio es ser radicalmente diferentes, no mejorar por pedacitos. Solo cuando eres radicalmente diferente es que los clientes les van a contar a sus amigos. Con mejoras incrementales, sí, hay ciertas funcionalidades donde puedes apostar a esas mejoras graduales, pero nosotros estamos buscando constantemente esos puntos clave que nos van a hacer radicalmente diferentes.
key_sentence: We're searching for those anchors that are fundamentally different, not incrementally better.
